loans.name: Musha

texts.en:
Musha is married and has four children, all  attend school. She rents a house without electricity and running water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Musha has operated a  home-based business to  make and sell dumplings and flat bread. She faces seasonal changes in her business. 

She wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat ,and sugar. 

She decided to join Yehu to access loans to increase her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar.

loans.name: Angel Antenor

texts.es:
Ángel tiene 58 años de edad, vive en casa propia junto a su conyuge no tiene carga familiar su esposa se dedica a la enseñanza en el colegio de lagunas,vive en el sectoir pogreso - lagunas una comunidad que se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, pesca, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

El se dedica al negocio de la carpinteria teniendo más de 10 años en el negocio, cuenta con clientes fijos desde hace varios años, por lo que es conocido por la actividad que realiza, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2500 nuevos soles para la compra de materia prima(madera), ya que cuenta con más clientes y tiene mayor cantidad de pedidos, y asi pueda cumplor con todos los pedidos pendientes, generandole mayores ganancias y mejorando su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Ángel is 58 years old and lives in his own home with his wife. He doesn't have any family responsibilities. His wife teaches at a college in Lagunas and they live in the Pogreso sector. Lagunas is a community which is involved in farming, business, raising animals and fishing. It is located in the province of Chiclayo which is part of the Lambayeque region on the north coast of Peru.

Ángel has worked in carpentry for over ten years and has had regular customers for many years, which is why he is well known for his work. He has applied for a loan of 2500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to buy materials (namely wood) as he now has more customers and a greater amount of orders. Being able to meet all of the pending orders means Ángel will be able to generate a higher income and improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to buy materials to complete all of his pending orders

loans.name: Khoem

texts.en:
Khoem, age 50, is a widow and lives in a village about 30 kilometers from Phnom Penh city. She has two children; one son is a driver for a company and one daughter is a garment factory worker. Khoem is a construction worker. 

Anyway, the stilts of her house seem not strong enough, and she wants to put up new ones. Hence, she decided to apply for a loan for that purpose.

loans.use: To put up new stilts on her house.

loans.name: Delcy Noemi

texts.es:
Noemi tiene 27 años de edad, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos, en casa familiar, en una comunidad grande en la zona urbana de Mocupe Nuevo y goza con buenas referencias personales y laborales de parte de sus vecinos, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

La actividad que realiza noemi es la crianza y venta de animales, como patos, cuyes y pavos,, desde hace años en su propio domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1500 nuevos soles para invertir en un ambiente de su domicilio asi darle mejor calidad de vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Noemi is 27 years old and lives with her husband and three children in the family home. She lives in a large community in the urban area of Mocupe Nuevo and has garnered good personal and work references from her neighbours.  Noemi's community is involved in farming, business and raising animals. It is located in the province of Chiclayo which is part of the Lambayeque region on the north coast of Peru.

Noemi has worked for years raising and selling animals such as ducks, guinea pigs and turkeys. She has applied for a loan of 1500 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to invest in another room in her home to give her family a better quality of life.

loans.use: to build another room in her home

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Jocelyn works hard to support her family.

She has a general store business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  Jocelyn is borrowing PHP 27,000 through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. for her general store business.

She successfully paid back her previous loan and now she requested the additional loan to further build her business.

Jocelyn has been sustaining her business activities through her past 18 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. in her sari-sari store

loans.name: Leopolda

texts.en:
Leopolda is 45 years old with one child.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a 10,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to purchase items to sell, like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Leopolda has borrowed and paid three loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for seven years and also earns an income from buying and selling chicken and vegetables.

She aspires to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase items to sell, like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida is 58 years old and married with four children.

She earns a living by farming rice in the Philippines. Leonida is borrowing 11,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) through NWTF to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies.

Leonida has been farming rice for six years and also earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fertilzers and other farm supplies

loans.name: Orlando

texts.es:
El señor Orlando es un experimentado cerrajero el cual a sus 15 años aprendió el oficio gracias a sus tíos y con el paso del tiempo fue independizándose hasta montar su propio taller con el cual gracias a Dios y a pesar de las adversidades ha logrado salir adelante junto con su familia.

Su mayor orgullo es haber construido su propia casa de madera donde vive actualmente con su esposa y dos hijos, construyo los muebles y casi todo lo encontrado en su humilde hogar es fabricado por el mismo.

Solicita un crédito para la compra de una maquina Pulidora de metal, esta herramienta es fundamental en su oficio y acelera mucho mas el proceso de trabajo.

Su principal sueño es enfocado en sus hijos puesto que vive en una zona donde el acceso a la educación es muy difícil y donde las personas que progresan es por que adquirieron conocimientos empíricamente y salen adelante al trabajar largas jornadas laborales que en muchas ocasiones solo les alcanza el dinero para comer. 

Orlando quiere que sus hijos vayan a una universidad y en un futuro no muy lejano vuelvan a su hogar como todos unos profesionales con altos cargos ejecutivos.
texts.en:
Orlando is an experienced locksmith. He learned about this trade at the age of 15 thanks to his aunt and uncle. Over time, he became independent to the point where he opened his own workshop. Thanks to God and in spite of adversity, he has managed to move forward along with his family.

He is most proud of having built his own wooden house, where he currently lives with his wife and two children. He built the furniture and almost everything in his humble house by himself.

He is applying for a loan to buy a metal polishing machine. This tool is fundamental to his business and greatly speeds up his working process.

His greatest dream is focused on his children, because he lives in an area where access to education is very difficult. The people who make progress are those who acquire knowledge and move ahead by working long hours, and often they barely make enough money to eat. Orlando wants his children to go on to university and to come home as professionals in high executive positions.

loans.use: to buy a polishing machine for his workshop.

loans.name: Battulga

texts.en:
Mr. Battulga, 44 years old, lives with his wife and five children in Ulaanbaatar, capital city of Mongolia. He began rendering taxi services to local people in 2013. Before this business, he had been selling newspapers at a bus stop. Now his elder two sons sell newspapers. 

Four years ago, using his previous loan, he bought a computer for his children, and now one of his children makes assignments for college students.

He is requesting  a loan of 1,000,000 MNT to buy automobile spare parts, such as tires and a bumper for his car. In this way, he can render taxi services without worrying about the safety of his passengers.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for his taxi service

loans.name: Filerma Del Rosario

texts.es:
Filerma de  57 anos, madre soltera con un hijo bajo su responsabilidad, el cual está estudiando, es originario de nagarote, lugar que está ubicado en la zona de occidente del país.  Se caracteriza por ser trabajadores, responsables, con ganas de superación personal. Lamentablemente por falta de recursos económicos no pudieron estudiar y se vieron en la necesidad de trabajar a temprana edad para ayudar con los gastos del hogar.
En la actualidad luchan día día para brindarles un futuro mejor a sus hijos y tiene por actividad económica una pulpería, es una pequeña tienda que vende productos comestibles, como: arroz, azúcar, leche, frijoles, pan, huevos, crema, jugos, queso, detergente, jabón. Esta mujer su rutina de trabajo es de unas doce horas diarias ofreciendo sus productos en su casa de habitación. El objetivo del crédito es invertir en capital de trabajo y surtir su negocio para obtener mejores ingresos. Filerma agradece la ayudar que los inversionistas realizan para ayudar a personas de escasos recursos económicos y financiar sus pequeños negocio pero que para ellos son su forma de vida y la subsistencia de sus familias.
texts.en:
Filerma is 57 years old and a single mother with one son under her care who is currently studying. Filerma is from Nagarote, an area which is located in the west of the country. She is hard working, responsible and has a desire to better herself. Unfortunately due to a lack of financial resources she was unable to study and had to start working at an early age to help with the household costs.

Filerma struggles day after day to give her children a better future. She runs a small grocery store selling edible products such as rice, sugar, milk, beans, bread, eggs, cream, juice and cheese as well as detergent and soap. This woman's work day consists of twelve hour days selling products from her home. 

The aim of this loan is to invest in working capital and restock her business to obtain greater earnings. Filerma is grateful for the help the lenders offer her and other people with scarce financial resources to finance their small businesses which are their way of life and subsistence for their families.

loans.use: to invest in working capital and restock her store which buys and sells edible products such as rice, beans, sugar, milk, bread, eggs, juice, biscuits and soft drink

loans.name: Ausberto

texts.es:
Ausberto tiene 56 años de edad, su estado civil es casado, vive en una comunidad de clima variado, su población es amable, se dedican a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, dicho lugar esta ubicado en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

Él brinda servicio de alquiler de yunta, hace mas de 10 años, aparte trabaja como obrero en la empresa agroindustrial de cayalti, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 3000 nuevos soles para lel arreglo de su techo y paredes de su casa la cual le dara mas comonidad a su familia, mejorando asi su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Ausberto, 56, is married and lives in an area with a varied climate. The local population is friendly and work in agriculture, trade, and livestock. His community is located in the province of Chiclayo, which belongs to the Lambayeque region on the north coast of Peru.

Ausberto offers a service renting out yokes for more than ten years. Aside from this, he also works at an agroindustrial company in Cayalti. He has applied for a loan of 3,000 Peruvian new soles to repair the roof and walls of his house, giving his family greater comfort. He will then improve his quality of life and that of his family.

loans.use: to invest in repairing the roof and walls of his house.

loans.name: Luvisminda

texts.en:
Luvisminda works hard to support her family. Luvisminda is married and has a buying and selling of furniture business in the Philippines.

She requested a 12,000 PHP (Philippines pesos) loan through NWTF to buy materials for her furniture business.

Luvisminda has been in this business for 16 years now.

In the future, Luvisminda would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy materials for her furniture business

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
Flora is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a buy and sell fish business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 10,000  through NWTF to buy fish to sell for her buy and sell fish business.

Flora has been in this business for eight years. She earns more income from food vending.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts, with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams of saving enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy fish to sell for her business

loans.name: Tata

texts.en: Tata is 28 years old. She is married and lives with her husband, an infant son and a pensioner mother-in-law. The family has no source of income, and they live in poverty. Tata decided to start a husbandry business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 1,500 Gel (Georgia lari). With the received credit, she will purchase a cow and will start producing dairy products to use for her family as food, as well as to sell locally. Tata will be able to generate income and will provide better living conditions for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a cow and start a husbandry business

loans.name: Linar

texts.en:
Linar is a married woman and has three kids who attend school. They live at a their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Linar has operated a farming business for the past six years. Her potential clients are neighbours and passersby. She dreams of expanding to large scale farming in the future. 

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase more seedlings and herbicides to kill pests. 

She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase more seedlings and herbicides to kill pests

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy blocks, cement, sand and iron sheeting

loans.name: Sokheng

texts.en:
Sokheng (in photo) is 41 years old and lives with her husband and children in a village about 18 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. She has four children: two sons and two daughters. Two of her children are married and live in separate homes; one is a construction worker and anther one attends school. 

Sokheng sells grocery items from home, while her husband is a construction worker. She wants to expand her grocery store by buying additional grocery items. Therefore, she has decided to apply for a loan.

loans.use: to buy more grocery inventory.

loans.name: Mercedita

texts.en:
As a married parent of eight children, Mercedita works hard to support her family.

She has a buy-and-sell dried fish business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from selling vegetables. Mercedita is borrowing PHP 15,000 through NWTF to buy dried fish to sell for her business.

Mercedita has been sustaining her business activities through her past 23 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to build and expand her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy dried fish to sell for her business

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane is 32 years old and married with four children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. 

Mary Jane has borrowed and paid five loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for three years and also earns an income from selling frozen foods.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. t

loans.name: Bukadde Magezi Devt Group

texts.en:
Safina is a 58-year-old vendor in a city outskirts market along the Kampala–Jinja road. She is a hardworking and creative mother of six children. She deals in the selling of fresh foods, such as fruits and vegetables supplied to her by farmers who bring their products to the market for sale.

After divorcing her husband, Safina resorted to vending in the market to earn a living and support her young family, and she has, since then, never looked back.

She says her hard work has helped her to survive in business among her peers; her major problem, however, is that agricultural food prices fluctuate so often, forcing her into losses quite often.

She intends to use the loan to acquire more stock, and in the future, acquire a permanent place from where to operate, since they always face the threat of market authorities evicting them from their current workplace.

loans.use: To buy fruits and vegetables for sale

loans.name: Zina

texts.en:
Zina is a 57-year-old widowed woman. She lives with her two children in the Khobi district. The family has no source of income and they live in poverty. 

Zina decided to start her own business in order to generate income. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative with Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of $300 to purchase clothes and bed-clothes. She will purchase the products at wholesale prices and then will resell them at a higher price in the Khobi district. 

She will generate income and will expand the business in future in order to provide better living conditions to her family.

loans.use: to begin to trade in clothes and bed-clothes in order to generate income

loans.name: Apu Condorsencca Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “APU CONDORSENCCA”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Paucartambo perteneciente a la provincia de Paucartambo y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Rosa ella es conviviente y tiene 41 años y tiene 5 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de venta y crianza de animales y también la socia tiene un terreno donde cultiva papa y maíz y también la socia cría los cuyes y gallinas los hace crecer y engordar y luego los vende en las diferentes ferias, por medio de este pequeño negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, el sueño de la socia es tener un local donde pueda vender los cuyes y gallinas. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar cuyes y gallinas y alimentos para los cuyes y gallinas.
La socia que esta pegada a la foto grupal se le tomo la foto despues de la reunion.

Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de animales, negocio de ganaderia, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de agricultura.
texts.en:
These members belong to the “APU CONDORSENCCA” communal bank, which is in the district of Paucartambo in the province of Paucartambo in the department of Cusco. Rosa is one of the members. She is 41, is in a common-law marriage and has 5 children. She has a business rearing and selling animals; she raises guinea pigs and chickens and fattens them for selling at different fairs She also has land where she grows potatoes and maize. It is through this small business that she provides for her children. Her dream is to have premises where she can sell her guinea pigs and chickens. She is asking for a loan to buy guinea pigs and chickens as well as animal feed for them.

The group photo has a small photo attached that was taken after the meeting.

The other group members work in animal sales, livestock, a grocery shop and agriculture.

loans.use: to buy guinea pigs and chickens and animal feed for them.

loans.name: Punku Mayor De Maras Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “PUNKU MAYOR DE MARAS”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de Maras, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Leonor  ella es casada y tiene 23 años y tiene 2 hijos; La socia trabaja en su negocio de tienda de abarrotes y también la socia se dedica al negocio de venta de truchas, la socia vende productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche y aceite, la socia trabaja desde las 8:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, la socia ya tiene 1 año en este negocio y le va muy bien, el sueño de la socia es ampliar el negocio de tienda de abarrotes. La socia solicita el crédito para comprar leche, azúcar, aceite y arroz.
 
 
Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de agricultura, negocio de venta de granos, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de venta de animales.

La socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
These members belong to the “Punku Mayor de Maras” communal bank.  This bank is located in the Maras district, Urubamba province in the department of Cusco.

One member, Leonor, is 23 years old.  She is married and has two children.  She works in her own business—a small grocery store.  She also works selling trout.  She sells basic necessities such as rice, sugar, milk, and oil, working from 8:00 a.m. until 6:00 p.m.  At this point, she has been doing this type of work for a year, and it is going really well for her.  

Her dream is to expand her grocery store business.  She is asking for this loan to buy milk, sugar, oil, and rice.  She thanks those who are part of her dream in this way and is committed to making her payments according to the established schedule.

The other group members work in agriculture, grain sales, animal sales, and a grocery store.

loans.use: to buy milk, sugar, oil, and rice

loans.name: Xojolá 9 Group

texts.es:
Mujeres emprendedora se ha convertido en el motor de su familia y de nuestro país que día a día con su esfuerzo se dedican a los que mejor saben hacer en el campo, es el caso de doña María de 34 años de edad residente en Suchitepéquez con un hijo de 7 años de edad que es estudiantes de la comunidad donde ella tiene que hacer el esfuerzo para poder sacar a la familia hacia adelante, (María es la que tiene una blusa de color rojo la que esta de primera fila en la derecha y es gordita).
	
La actividad que ella dignamente realiza es la producción de banano en su aldea, dicha actividad lo aprendió de sus padres desde hace 25 años que lo han venido haciendo  para luego venderlas en el mayoreo de su comunidad, es la única actividad que ella realiza para poder tener un ingreso económico y obtener ganancias y mejorar la condición de vida en la que ella y su familia viven.

El uso respectivo que ella le dará al crédito que ella está realizando es para la compra de insecticidas para el mantenimiento de bananos con que ella cuenta en su terreno para que mejore la producción de las mismas.

Ella es un ejemplo de las mujeres emprendedoras y es por ello que se unieron a ella un grupo de mujeres para emprender junto a ella el negocio para un desarrollo mejor de su comunidad.

Una de las visiones de María es ver crecer a su hijo y convertirse en un profesional en el mañana.
texts.en:
Female entrepreneurs have become the backbone of their families and of the country. Day after day, they dedicate their efforts to the fields they know best. This is the case of María, 34, who lives in Suchitepéquez with her seven-year-old son. He studies in the community where she works hard to provide for her family. In the photo, María is on the right wearing a red shirt.

María's business activity is producing banana trees in her village. She learned about this business from her parents 25 years ago and has been working in this field ever since. She sells the banana trees at a wholesale store in her village. This is her only source of income, allowing her to improve the conditions in which she and her family live.

She will use this loan to buy insecticide to maintain her banana tree crops, thereby improving her production of banana trees. She is an example of a female entrepreneur, which is why she joined a group of women to grow their businesses together and develop their local community.

One of María's dreams is to see her son grow and become a professional in the future.

loans.use: to maintain her banana trees.

loans.name: Hellen

texts.en:
Hellen is a 43-year-old widowed lady and supports a family of five children aged between 18 and 12 years old. She operates a pharmacy business  where she sells different types of drugs. It has been in operation for the last 14 years, earning an income of KES 35,000.  

Hellen was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer and is now servicing her second loan of KES 20,000. She intends to use this amount to add more stock of assorted drugs to her business to exceed her customers’ expectations.  

She plans to use the anticipated income to expand her business and educate her children. She hopes to have a bright future and with a lot of success and provide the best quality education to her children in the near future.

loans.use: to add more stock of assorted drugs

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.en:
As a married parent of four children, Magdalena works hard to support her family.

She has a frozen foods vending business in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from food vending.  Magdalena is borrowing PHP 10,000 through NWTF to purchase additional stock of frozen foods to sell for her business.

Magdalena has been sustaining her business activities through her past 15 loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock of frozen foods to sell

loans.name: Edwardson

texts.en:
Edwardson is 26 years old and married with two kids. 

He has managed a farm business for five years. He earns PHP 10,000 per cropping so he can save so that he has enough money to sustain the daily needs of his family. 

To have additional income, he is asking for a loan amounting to PHP 12,000 to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and insecticide.  Edwardson dreams that he can save enough money for the future of his family.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer, pesticide, and insecticide.

loans.name: Monaliza

texts.en:
Monaliza is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a fishing business in the Philippines. 

She is borrowing PHP 12,000 through NWTF to purchase additional fishing net for her fishing business.

Monaliza has been in this business for 16 years. She earns more income from making nipa roofing.

She has been sustaining her business activities through her own efforts with the help of the loans from NWTF. She dreams to save money to expand her business in the future.

loans.use: to purchase additional fishing net

loans.name: Esther

texts.es: Esther comró muebles de salas, comedores cuadros y artesanias provenientes del municipio de Sanpues, lugar donde sus habitantes son expertos en la elaboración este tipo de productos, que gusta mucho a su clientela. Con su inversión obtuvo mayores utilidades, pues invirtió en algo nuevo. Actualmente se dedica con más enfasis, a la compra y venta de muebles y articulos de tocador. Esther agradece a sus financiadores y pide que continuen con esta iniciativa para poder mejorar la calidad de visa de los empresarios. Su nueva inversión para la cual solicita un crédito a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, la aplicará a la compra en un mayor volumen de juegos de alcobas, y comedores para venderlos a su clientela, a la cual quiere tener satisfecha para que su inversión producto de Kiva tenga éxito.
texts.en:
Previously Esther bought living and dining room furniture, paintings and artisanal work from the municipality of Sanpues. The people of this area are experts in the creation of these types of products and her customers are very happy with them.  Esther gained a greater profit from this investment so she re-invested in something new. At the moment she is focussing more on buying and selling furniture and dressing room items. 

Esther is grateful to all of the lenders and asks that they continue this initiative to improve the quality of life of the entrepreneurs. She is applying for a loan from Fundación Mario Santo Domingo which she will use to buy more bedroom sets and dining tables to sell to her customers. Esther hopes they will be satisfied with these products so that her Kiva investment will be successful.

loans.use: to buy more bedroom and dining sets to resell

loans.name: Mbeyu

texts.en:
Mbeyu is married and has children. The family lives in a rental that has electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Mbeyu sells charcoal from her home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces competition from other charcoal vendors in the area.

Mbeyu decided to join Yehu so she could take out loans for her business. She is applying for 20,000 KES to buy more sacks of charcoal to sell.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal to sell

loans.name: Ericka Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Ericka es una mujer de 36 años de edad, casada y madre de 2 hijos que aún están a su cargo. Ericka dio inicio en el mundo de los negocios cuando apenas vendía unos que cuantos dulces para los niños en su domicilio, luego observo que le fue muy bien y decidió invertir para comprar más productos para diversificar y agrandar su negocio. Al cabo de unos años miro que no poseía competencia alguna y retomo la iniciativa de seguir reinvirtiendo en su negocio ya que le ha ido excelente.

Actualmente Ericka por la mal situación económica, ella desea solicitar un préstamo para comprar más productos como bombones, churritos, galletas, panes, azúcar, arroz entre otros productos que presentan mucha demanda en su negocio. Ella confía que el crédito le será de mucha utilidad ya que podrá vender más productos y obtener ganancias que será reinvertidas nuevamente en el negocio. Entre sus principales metas está lograr hacer que el negocio crezca más y la búsqueda de un nuevo producto que tenga una gran demanda en el mercado y que solo ella lo pueda ofertar.
texts.en:
Ericka is a 36 year-old woman.  She is married and is the mother of two children, both of whom are still under her care.  Ericka got started in the business world when she would sell sweets to children out of her home.  When she saw that it was going really well for her, she decided to make an investment in order to purchase more products.  And so she diversified and expanded her business.  After a number of years she saw that she didn’t have any real competition and took the initiative once again to invest in her business, because it has gone so well for her.

Currently, due to the bad economic situation, Ericka wants to ask for a loan to buy more products such as marshmallows, cheese puffs, cookies, bread, sugar, and rice, among other high-demand items.  She has confidence that this loan will be very useful because she will be able to sell more products and, in this way, get better earnings.  She will reinvest these in her business once again.  Among her chief goals is making her business grow even more, along with looking for a product that is in great demand in the market and that she can offer exclusively.

loans.use: to buy more products such as marshmallows, cheese puffs, cookies, bread, sugar, and rice.

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana is a 30-year-old married woman from the Lanchkhuti district. She lives with her school-aged son and earns a living by working at the local restaurant as a waitress. 

Nana generates insignificant income that isn't enough for living in normal conditions. So she decided to start another parallel activity that will increase her salary. Nana's loan request was rejected several times because of her unstable financial condition. 

Finally MFO Credo approved her application within the Start-Up program that gives poor people a chance to start or re-start businesses. She plans to purchase a stock of various home products and start trading in her free time. This activity will greatly assist Nana, as her income will increase and it help her to deal with financial difficulties. 

Nana and her son will be really grateful for the help and await your kindness.

loans.use: To  get an additional source of income and start a trading business

loans.name: Belindah

texts.en:
Belindah is 35 years old and married to Rodgers. She supports a family of three children. Her husband adds additional income to the family. She operates a retail business which has been in operation for five years, earning an income of KES 30,000.  

Belindah was introduced to VisionFund Kenya by a credit officer and is now servicing her third loan of KES 27,000. She intends to use this amount to add more stock of retail goods like sugar, cooking oil, and washing detergents to her store.

She plans to use the anticipated income to expand her business and educate her children. She hopes to have a bright future with a lot of success and to provide the best quality education to her children.

loans.use: to buy more stock of retail goods like sugar, cooking oil, and washing detergents

loans.name: Sada

texts.en:
Sada is married. She has seven children, all of whom have graduated from school and are working. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

For years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. Sada dreams of establishing a hotel in the future. 

With the KES 10,000, she wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar

loans.name: Eufemia

texts.es:
Eufemia tiene 53 años, vive con su conyuge e hija de 14 años, en casa familiar, en una comunidad grande en la zona urbana de Mocupe - Lagunas, goza con buenas referencias personales y laborales de parte de sus vecinos, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

La actividad que realiza Eufemia es la crianza y venta de animales, como patos, cerdos y pollos, desde hace 3 años en su propio domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2000 nuevos soles para la compra de animales para que genere un mayor ingreso y asi pueda mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Eufemia is 53 years old and lives with her husband and 14 year old daughter in the family home. She lives in a large community in the urban area of Mocupe - Lagunas and has good personal and work references from her neighbours.  Eufemia's community is involved in farming, business and raising animals. It is located in the province of Chiclayo which is part of the Lambayeque region on the north coast of Peru.

Eufemia has worked raising and selling animals from home such as ducks, pigs and chickens for three years. She has applied for a loan of 2000 nuevos soles from Edpyme Alternativa to buy animals so that she can generate a greater income and improve the quality of life of herself and her family.

loans.use: to buy animals and merchandise for her store

loans.name: Tazagul

texts.en:
Tazagul is 43 years old. She is single and is living with her mother and her brother's family. Her father died in the first Karabakh war and her mother was sick for long years, she needs care. Tazagul so loves her mother, she takes care of her and, therefore, can’t marry. The family members are IDP - Internally Displaced Persons from Fuzuli City and now they are living in the Fuzuli region, Kurdmahmudlu village. 

Tazagul has a small store, where she basically sells cleaning products. Today, Tazagul wants to support her business and, for this reason, she has applied to Komak Credit Union for a loan in the amount of AZN 1,900 (Azerbaijan New Manat) to repair the exterior of the store. She is thankful to the Kiva organization for its aid. 

In the future, Tazagul wants to increase the area of her store and in her personal life wants to get married and have a child.

loans.use: to pay for repairs to the exterior of her store.

loans.name: Lolita

texts.en:
Lolita, 57, is widowed and has two children. She works hard managing both her household and a business and providing an income to cover daily expenses.

Lolita runs a store where she sells footwear, sandals and other general merchandise. She earns a profit by buying from wholesalers and then selling at a small profit. Customers are attracted by her low prices and other options she offers. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns at least 500 PHP every day.

To help her boost business, Lolita is applying for a 9,000 PHP loan to buy more and different varieties of footwear to expand her product inventory. She hopes that her capital will increase in direct proportion to her profits.

All CCT community clients, including Lolita, are organized into fellowship groups of fifteen to thirty members who meet on a weekly basis. There they share stories of their work, repay microfinance loans and draw strength and inspiration from their study of the Word of God.

loans.use: To buy additional stocks of shoes and other products needed in her business.

loans.name: Simona Del Camen

texts.es: Apoyar a Simona en la compra de víverés, telas, insumos para elaborar ropa y mercancia como ropa interior, sueteres etc, fue fortalecer sus dos negocios y esto fue logrado mediante su crédikiva,porque ha logrado mejorar su utilidad y poder realizar mas gastos . Sus ventas se incrementaron mejoró su capacidad de pago, y se siente hoy mas relajada pues ha logrado mejorar tambien su vivienda. En la actualidad está aplicando a un credikiva nuevamente y planea invertir un 40% de este la compra de materiales constructivos para hacer un levantamiento de muros en el negocio y un 60% en la compra de mercancias como víverés, telas, insumos para elaborar ropa y mercancia como ropa interior, sueteres para vender mucho mas. Ella agradece a sus finaciadores diciendo: " Que Dios los bendiga por la obra que están ejecutando."
texts.en:
A previous Kiva loan helped Simona to buy food supplies, fabric, materials to make clothing and goods such as underwear and sweaters. This strengthened her two businesses as she managed to increase her business usefulness and was able to invest more. Her sales increased, she improved her ability to pay back her loan and now she feels more relaxed as she has also managed to improve her house.

Simona is now asking for a new Kiva loan. She will use 40% of it in buying construction materials to erect walls for her business and 60% in buying goods such as food provisions, fabric, materials to make clothing and items such as underwear and sweaters so that she can sell much more. She is grateful to lenders, saying "God bless you for the work you are doing."

loans.use: to invest 40% in construction materials to build walls for her business and 60% in buying goods such as provisions, fabric, materials to make clothing and items such as underwear and sweaters.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy an industrial stove and ingredients

loans.name: Nzingo

texts.en:
Nzingo is a married woman. She has seven children. She lives at her own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past ten years, she has operated an open air food stall business. Her potential customers are market dwellers and neighbors. She faces a major challenge of seasonality of products in the market.

With the KES 10,000, she wants to purchase sacks of beans, cooking fat oil, wheat flour, and rice. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase sacks of beans, cooking fat oil, wheat flour, and rice.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josphine is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a water-selling business. She sells from home to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is the high cost of transportation. With the loan she is requesting of KES 20,000, she wants to purchase a handcar for transportation and water for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a handcar for transportation and water for resale.

loans.name: Gladies

texts.en:
Gladies is a married woman. She has seven children who attend school. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Gladies has operated a farming business for the past 6 years. Her potential clients are neighbors and passersby. She dreams of expanding to large scale farming in the future. 

With the KES 30,000, she wants to purchase more seedlings and herbicides to kill pests. She decided to join Yehu to access financial support to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase more seedlings and herbicides to kill pests

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is 20 years old and lives in the town of Siroko in the Mbale region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 1 year, Lydia has been working hard to manage her small clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand  business, Lydia has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes for sale and will help Lydia to generate greater profits and pay her children's medical bills. Lydia hopes that in the future she will be able to open up a retail shop. 

Lydia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more clothes for sale.

loans.name: Jackline

texts.en:
Jackline is 20 years old and lives in the town of Siroko in the Mbale region of Uganda.  She is married and has one child who is currently in school. For the past 2 years, Jackline has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential goods such as rice, sugar, beans and soda. 

To help expand  business, Jackline has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential goods for sale and will help Jackline to generate greater profits and improve on her family's standard of living. Jackline hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Jackline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more essential goods for sale.

loans.name: Jamilee

texts.en: Jamilee is 23 years old and single. She owns and manages a generic drugstore within the town proper. She aims to make her business viable and profitable in order to generate sufficient income to help her parents financially. She planned to acquire more stocks of various medicines to resell but she has insufficient capital. For this reason, she would like to access financial assistance from Kiva lenders in an amount of PHP 30,000 to purchase more stocks of medicine like Ventolin, antibiotics, and vitamins and various milks to resell. Through patience and strong determination, she believes that someday she will further improve the business.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of medicine like Ventolin, antibiotics, and vitamins and various milks to resell.

location.town: Brgy. San Pedro, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Londa

texts.en: Londa is 63 years old. She lives with her son in the Chkhorotsku district. Londa is involved in agricultural activities. In particular, she has a plot of land where she grows 80 nut trees, 20 kiwi trees and has 0.5 hectare agricultural land where maize is grown. Londa is very hardworking. She does her best to insure a good harvest. She sells the harvested products at local markets. Along with these agricultural activities, Londa decided to start a husbandry business and requested a loan. The Start Up program, which is a joint initiative between Kiva and Credo, enables her to get a loan of 1,000 GEL to purchase a cow. Once the cow is purchased, she will start producing dairy products to sell and increase the income. With increased income, she will improve the living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a cow in order to start a husbandry business.

loans.name: Atwagala Development Group

texts.en:
Ritah is a member of the Atwagala group located in central Kampala. Ritah is a 28-year-old single mother of two after divorcing from her husband who had married another wife and stopped taking care of Ritah and her children. Her two children are both in school.

Ritah is a farmer practicing piggery in the outskirts of Kampala. She supplements her income with money earned from her side job where she works as support staff. She resorted to farming after finding it hard to feed her family following divorce. 

She will use the loan to buy more pigs to increase her piggery project. Her major problem has been money to buy pig feeds given that the pigs eat a lot. She is a hardworking lady very focused on her dreams for a better family.

loans.use: to buy pigs.

loans.name: Fabiana

texts.en:
Fabiana is a businesswoman from Plaridel. She is 57 years old and strives hard to feed her family. For the past few years, she operated a sari-sari store and she constantly worked with PMPC for all her capital needs. Recently, she obtained a loan to restock her store with items like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.
Fabiana hopes to buy a farm lot to cultivate.

loans.use: to restock her store with items like canned goods, oil, and soy sauce.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en: Esterlita is 58 years old and resides in Plaridel. She joined PMPC to access the programs and services of the coop. She's accessing another loan for additional working capital for her farming business. The loan will pay for seedlings and compost. She hopes to sustain her business and support her family.

loans.use: to pay for seedlings and compost

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene is 27 years old and married with one child.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a buy-and-sell nipa roofing business in the Philippines. Arlene has requested a PHP 13,500 loan through NWTF to buy more nipa to sell.

Arlene has borrowed and repaid six loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the nipa roofing business for two years and also earns an income from farming rice and fishing.

She aspires to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: to buy more nipa to sell

loans.name: Siphira

texts.en:
Hello lenders! Meet Siphira, a very hardworking, humble and ever-smiling mother of 3 lovely children. She hails from the Chuka area of Kenya, an area that is located on the slopes of Mount Kenya (one of the tallest mountains in Africa). She is married and together with her husband they work as a team supporting each other as spouses, parents and mixed farmers. Chuka area has one of the best weather conditions that favors crop and animal farming and through hard work and dedication she has been practicing farming for the past 8 years and through all those years she has been making great strides in farming and profits margins.

Siphira's source of income is tea farming, crop farming and a small personal business that she does so as to make ends meet. Her love for dairy farming can be shown through the nickname she has given her cow “Chia magochi”.

Chuka area has a high population and the demand for cereals is high but there is a low supply. That is why Siphira saw a great opportunity to generate income and hence she is kindly seeking a loan to buy cereals and to sell her neighbors and in the local market. Through profits from selling cereals, Siphira will achieve her ultimate goal of improving her living conditions and providing a good education to her school-going children.

Siphira is an ambitious woman and very visionary. Her goal is to save more money through profits and be able to open a large cereal selling shop where she will be selling all types of cereals at a fair price to her village and other markets in other towns.

loans.use: to buy cereals.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a married mother of one child, who attends school. They live in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

For years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Lucy dreams of establishing a hotel in the future. 

With the KES 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and charcoal. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business

loans.use: to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and charcoal

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a married woman with five children all under her care. She and her husband own a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

Nancy wants to start a vegetable- and fruit-selling business. Her major goal is to run a leading fruit-vending business in the area to raise her profits.

With the KES 50,000 loan, she wants to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruit such as oranges, mangoes, watermelon, and pawpaw. She decided to join Yehu to get financial support.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and sacks of fruit such as oranges, mangoes, watermelon, and pawpaw.

loans.name: Amina's Group

texts.en:
Amina's group is composed of four hard-working women. Amina is 18 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past two years, Amina has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential goods such as rice, sugar, beans and soda. 

To help expand  business, Amina has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential goods to sell and will help Amina generate greater profits and take care of herself. Amina hopes that in the future, will be able to complete her studies. 

Amina is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to purchase more essential goods such as rice, sugar, beans and soda to sell.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to have capital to buy gold and silver and create handicrafts

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela tiene 46 años de edad, vive con su esposo e hijo, en casa familiar, en una comunidad grande en la zona urbana de cayalti; goza con buenas referencias personales y laborales por parte de sus vecinos, su población se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

Se dedica a la actiidad de siembra y venta de alfalfa, cuenta con terreno de cultimo propio, con 10 años aproximadamente en el negocio, tiene su negocio en la av. Cajamarca en una esquina del mercado de cayalti, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 2000 nuevos, para la siembra de alfalfa. De esta manera hacer crecer su negocio y mejorar su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
Graciela is 46 years old and lives with her husband and son in the family's own home. Graciela and her family live in a large urban community in Cayalti, in Chiclayo Province in the Lambayeque Region along Peru's northern coast. People in Cayalti work as farmers, ranchers, and run small businesses. 

Graciela has raised and sold alfalfa for about ten years on a plot of land along Av. Cajamarca on a corner next to the Cayalti market. Graciela has applied for a loan of 2,000 new soles from Edpyme Alternativa for planting alfalfa. She has strong personal and professional references from neighbors. This loan will allow Graciela to grow her business and improve her quality of life and her family's.

loans.use: to plant and care for her alfalfa crop.

loans.name: Concesa

texts.en:
Concesa works hard to support her family. She is married and has a motorcycle transport business in the Philippines.

She requested a PHP 22,000 loan through NWTF to buy gasoline and other materials for her motorcycle.

Concesa has been in this business for five years now.

In the future, she would like to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy gasoline and other materials for her motorcycle

loans.name: Mkambe

texts.en:
Mkambe is a married woman with five children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

She has operated a retail shop business for the past one year, selling household consumables like wheat flour, maize flour, and sugar. She faces a major challenge of creditors taking too long to repay for goods taken on credit. 

With the loan she is requesting, she wants to purchase a stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a stock of sugar, rice, maize flour, and wheat flour

loans.name: Badengnadjourou Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe  BADENGNADJOUROU  sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 29 ans, et ont en moyenne 2 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles traditionnelles au quartier BABEMBA un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont à leur douzième prêt solidaire avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame AMINATA débout à la deuxième position de la gauche vers la droite sur la photo dans ce groupe des femmes BADENGNADJOUROU, fait la vente des mangues.
Elle compte acheter avec son argent des quantités importantes de mangues dans les villages environnants de la ville de SIKASSO.
Madame AMINATA est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle par la qualité de ses produits pour la revendre en détail  au marché à une clientèle composée d’ homme et de femme au comptant et à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 10 000 francs CFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The four members of the BADENGNADJOUROU group are married women and they are, on average, 29 years old with two children each.  Most of them live in traditional families in Babemba, a working-class neighborhood of the city of Sikasso (third administrative region of Mali).  In order to meet the needs of their customers, they are taking their 12th solidarity loan with Kiva's partner, the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

Aminata, a member of the group, sells mangoes.  In the photo, she is the woman standing second from the left.  Aminata is planning to buy large quantities of mangoes in the villages around Sikasso.  Thanks to the quality of her merchandise, she receives a high demand from her customers.  She resells mangoes at the market, on a retail basis.  Her customers are both men and women and they pay her in cash or on credit.  Aminata is expecting to make an average monthly profit of 10,000 CFA francs, part of which will be used to repay her loan and the interest, while the rest of the money will go into savings.

loans.use: to buy mangoes.

loans.name: Shamimu's Group

texts.en:
Shamimu's group comprises four hardworking women. Shamimu is 18 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. For the past three years, Shamimu has been working hard to manage her poultry farm, which sells chicken birds. 

To help expand her business, Shamimu has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more birds and chicken birds for sale, and will help Shamimu to generate greater profits and improve her family’s standard of living. Shamimu hopes that in the future, she will be able to build a residential house. 

Shamimu is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more birds and chicken birds for sale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to buy groundnuts to make into paste

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a farmer from Plaridel. She is 61 years old and strives hard to support her family. 

Recently, she applied a loan to pay for land and seedbed preparation. She hopes to earn more profit for this cropping season.

loans.use: to pay for land and seedbed preparation

loans.name: Khalicha

texts.en:
Khalicha is 54 years old. She is a hardworking and industrious woman. Khalicha decided to begin own business with selling children’s clothes 18 years ago because she needed money. During the 18 years, she has been busy with buying and selling clothes. 

She has a store in a local market where she sells a variety of women’s clothes. Khalicha renews the assortment of her goods every season because the business struggle is big in a local market. She uses the profit from her business to improve her living condition. She is a careful mother for her children and a lovely wife for her husband. Her husband, Sangin, is a worker. Their children are adults. 

Khalicha is going to buy women’s clothes for the new season, so she is asking for a loan of 5,000 Somoni. She awaits your mercy.

loans.use: to buy women's clothes for increasing working capital.

loans.name: Corazon

texts.en:
Corazon is 50 years old and married with five children.

She works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines, and requested a PHP 10,000 loan through NWTF to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc. to sell.

Corazon has borrowed and paid nine loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns an income from farming rice, fishing and pig fattening.

She aspires to save enough money so she could afford to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy items to sell like shampoo, groceries, etc.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more stock for his store.

loans.name: Ega

texts.en:
Ega is a divorced mother of four children, all of whom graduated from school and are working. They live at their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. 

For years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. Ega dreams of establishing a hotel in the future. 

With the KES 30,000 loan, she wants to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase three bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat, and sugar

loans.name: Habiba

texts.en:
Habiba is 19 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past year, Habiba has been working hard to manage her small clothing business, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Habiba has requested a loan of 250,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes for sale, and will help Habiba to generate greater profits and take care of her family. Habiba hopes that in the future, she will be able to become a better businesswoman. 

Habiba is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes for sale.

loans.name: Danaya 1 Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe DANAYA 1  est constitué de 9 femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42  ans et 5 enfants et vivant toutes dans des  familles polygames à TIEFAGALA, un des villages de BOUGOUNI, 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles hivernale. 
Elles sont à leur 4ème prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
Le  riz  est la spéculation cultivée de Tenimba, la 1ère femme assise dans la photo de la gauche vers la droite.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, la semence et payer les frais de labour  et  de sarclage pour exploiter 1 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village, au marché, après la récolte à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice  de 60.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de rembourser son prêt et  d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes de leur ménage.
texts.en: The Danaya 1 group is made up of nine married women who, on average, are 42 years old and have five children and are all living in polygamous families in Tiefagala, one of the villages of Bougouni, third administrative region of Mali. They are working with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution in order to better run their seasonal agricultural businesses. They are on their fourth loan with the microfinance institution, having properly paid back their previous loans. Rice is the crop cultivated by Tenimba, the first woman seated in the photo from left to right. With her loan, she expects to buy fertilizers, herbicides and seeds and to pay for the costs of labor and hoeing to operate one hectare of land. The production will be sold at the village level at the market after the harvest to a clientele made up of men and women. She expects to make a profit of 60,000 francs CFA per field. This profit will allow her to pay back her loan and also to help her husband with daily household expenses.

loans.use: purchase fertilizers, herbicides and seeds and to pay for the costs of labor and hoeing.

loans.name: Constance

texts.en: Constance is married, and has seven children. She owns a house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. For the past six years, she has operated a rental housing business. Her potential customers are her tenants. Her major challenge is seasonality in the business.With her KES 30,000 loan she wants to improve her rental house by painting it. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her living standards.

loans.use: to improve her rental house by painting it

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different kinds of vehicle and bike parts for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy manure, irrigation equipment, fertilizers and seeds.

loans.name: Scovia

texts.en:
Scovia is 23 years old and lives in the town of Mbale in the Mbale region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, with one of them currently in school. For the past four years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her small clothing business. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 800,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more new clothes to sell and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and pay school fees for her children. Scovia hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy land and begin building. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training.

loans.use: to buy more new clothes to sell

loans.name: Salama

texts.en: Salama is a married woman with six children, all of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. For the past two years, she has operated a charcoal selling business. She sells from home to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge in the business is the high cost of transportation. With the loan of KES 20,000 she is requesting, she wants to purchase 20 bags of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase 20 bags of charcoal for resale

loans.name: Mbetsa

texts.en:
Mbetsa is married with ten children. Her husband is a carpenter and he supports his family financially. They live in their own house, which has neither electricity nor piped water. 

Mbetsa operates a business selling water at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality and other food stall operators in her business. 

With 10,000 KES she wants to diversify and start a firewood selling business by purchasing bundles of firewood for resale. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to start a firewood selling business and purchase bundles of firewood for resale

loans.name: Maryamu

texts.en:
Maryamu is a thirty-five-year-old farmer from Kwankwani. As a member of Babban Gona, Maryamu is excited about the opportunity to finally have access to credit, good markets and a trained agronomist. Like all Babban Gona members, Maryamu can earn up to $2000 per hectare this season from growing maize. This is more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields thirty bags per hectare, which is more than double the national average of fourteen. 

Maryamu is ambitious, so she is aiming to reap thirty-five bags per hectare this season.  When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money to educate my children: Musa, Alheri, and  Vicent. My overall goal is to ensure my children are educated and have professional jobs.” With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving these goals.

loans.use: To access high quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield

loans.name: Kibib

texts.en: Kibibi is a mother of two children, both of whom have graduated from school and are working. They live in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For years, Kibibi has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of price fluctuation in her business. With her KES 10,000 loan she wants to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. She dreams of establishing a hotel in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and sugar

loans.name: Saratu

texts.en: Saratu is a maize farmer and member of Babban Gona. Saratu joined Babban Gona primarily to create a better future for her children: Esther, Diyana, and  Batalamawus. Saratu is excited that Babban Gona offers a lasting solution to ending the cycle of poverty. For the first time, Saratu will have access to quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed. Without this loan, she would be subjected to buying these products in the open market where they are not only very expensive but are often diluted with external products such as sand. With access to high quality inputs, Saratu can reap up to 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14 and  earn up to $2,000/hectare, more than three times the average Nigerian farmer’s annual income. When asked how she plans to spend the income she will make this year as a Babban Gona member, she said, “I plan to use the money  to expand my farmland.” Saratu is not thinking about this year alone; she expressed that her longterm goal is to “become the most profitable farmer in my community.” With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this goal.

loans.use: to access high quality supplies such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Cathrine

texts.en: Cathrine is a married woman with four school-going children. They live in their own house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees. For the past year, she has operated a tailoring business, operating from the market, where neighbours and passersby are potential customers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase cloth materials and needles, and repair her broken sewing machine.

loans.use: to purchase cloth materials and needles, and repair her broken sewing machine.

loans.name: Kapicha

texts.en: Kapicha is a married mother of nine children, all of whom attend school. They live in their own house that has neither electricity nor piped water. For years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. With her KES 20,000 loan she wants to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and charcoal. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business. Kapicha dreams of establishing a hotel in the future.

loans.use: to purchase 3 bundles of wheat flour, cooking fat and charcoal

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
Juan Carlos tiene 39 años de edad, su estado civil es soltero, vive en el distrito de Cayaltí, comunidad que se dedica a la agricultura, comercio y ganadería, ubicada en la Provincia de Chiclayo que pertenece a la Región Lambayeque, costa norte del Perú.

Él se dedica a la fabricación de productos metálicos como puertas, ventanas, objetos de metal, con más de 3 años de experiencia, su negocio se encuentra ubicado al costado de su domicilio, ha solicitado un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 3000 nuevos soles para la compra de productos metálicos para abastecerse de mayor materia prima y asi poder atender los pedidos que tiene y también ofrecerle una mejor atencion a sus clientes, lo que permitira aumentar sus ingresos, mejorando sus ganancias y por ende la calidad de vida de él y su familia.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos is 39 years old, single, and lives in the city of Cayaltí, where most people work as farmers or ranchers or run small businesses. Cayaltí is in the Lambayeque Region along the northern coast of Peru. 

Juan Carlos has run a business making metal goods for over three years. He makes doors, windows, and other objects in a shop next to his home. He has applied for a loan of 3,000 new soles from Edpyme Alternativa to increase his stock of wholesale metal supplies so he can fill customer orders and offer his customers better service. These investments and improvements will allow Juan Carlos to boost business earnings and his income, and thus improve his family's quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials so he can meet all of his outstanding orders.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, drinks and provisions to expand her business.

loans.name: Edward

texts.en:
Edward is 41 years old. He is married to Virginia, and together they have been blessed with three children; one is in secondary school and the other two in primary school.

Edward runs a bakery, a business he has done for the last 12 years, earning a monthly income of KES 13,500. Peter has requested his third loan with VisionFund Kenya which he will use to purchase flour, cooking oil, and charcoal. He successfully repaid his previous loans.

Edward has however encountered problems with his baking/cooking  and will use the anticipated profits to repair his machine. His dreams and hopes for the future are to own a bigger shop and open a shop as well for his wife.

loans.use: to purchase flour, cooking oil, and charocoal

loans.name: Butanda  Bakyara Twimutsyane Group

texts.en:
Butanda Bakyara is an old group located in Kagarama in the Ntungamo district. The group is comprised of men and women whose major activities are related to agriculture and few are engaged in other business. They applied for loan as a group, and they will divide the money amongst themselves. 

Apparently they are limited by little output as a community because of poor farming methods. Their prime target therefore is to mulch their plantations such that they can yield much more. Harriet will specifically buy mulch and hire labourers to collect cow dung for her banana plantation. She is optimistic her yields will gradually improve and so will her income. She will then be able to take her children to better schools and also better meet their other needs.

loans.use: To buy mulch and cow dung

loans.name: Leatu

texts.en:
Leatu remembers not being able to feed her family during a particularly bad harvest. This was before she became a Babban Gona Member. Now Leatu, like all Babban Gona members, has access to professional managers and trained agronomists. She can earn up to $2000 per hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. 
When asked what she would like to accomplish with her extra income, Leatu emphasised her desire to improve the lives of her children. She said: “in 5 years, I want to ensure my children are educated, and can secure professional jobs.” With this loan, she is well on her way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: To access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seeds in order to double her income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase different kinds of electronics items, like cables, light fans, plugs, bulbs, radios, and switches.

loans.name: Cissy

texts.en: Cissy used her previous loan to buy cattle to sell. She is a hardworking lady, who is a farmer growing crops such as banana, as well as rearing cattle and owning rentals. She faces challenges of price fluctuation and changes in weather, especially during the dry season when the cattle lack grass and water. However, she hopes of having a self-supporting and healthy family. Cissy needs a loan to buy more cattle to sell.

loans.use: to buy more cattle to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase his capital and buy 100 kilos of rice and 60 kilos of beans for resale to earn more

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a lady and has no children. She lives at a rental house that has electricity and piped water.

Agnes has operated a beauty salon business for the past three years, operating at the market for passersby and town dwellers. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business.

With the loan, she is requesting she wants to buy stock of hair braids, shampoo and weaves into her beauty salon business. She dreams of expanding her business to earn more income in the future.

loans.use: to buy hair braids, shampoo and weaves for her beauty salon business.

loans.name: Nyekundire Group

texts.en:
Syrus is a Ugandan man who is 26 years old and married. He has two children, ages 2 and 4 years old, and the family resides in Kyarushesha -rural Kagadi. He also has siblings for dependents.

Syrus is a farmer and a produce dealer and has been doing this business since 2010 as his major source of income to support his family. He has applied for a loan of 500,000 UGX through his Nyekundire Group in order to buy organic fertilizers and hire labor so that he can expand his farming project and also increase his coffee yield.

Syrus’s dream is to build a family house and expand his farming project.  However, he faces the challenges of limited capital and price fluctuations. These will soon be history with continuous financial boost from kiva lenders through UGAFODE.

loans.use: To buy organic fertilizers and hire labor

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase cigarettes, drinks and provisions to expand her business.

loans.name: Alh. Magaji

texts.en: Alh. Magaji remembers not being able to feed his family as a result of a particularly bad harvest. This was before he became a Babban Gona Member. Now,  Alh. Magaji, like all Babban Gona members, can earn up to $2,000 per hectare this season from growing maize, more than three times the Nigerian farmer’s annual income. The average Babban Gona farmer yields 30 bags/hectare, double the national average of 14. However, Alh. Magaji is ambitious and is aiming to reap at least 40 bags per hectare this season because this loan will give him access to high quality inputs such as improved seeds.  “In five years, I want to ensure other members of my community are lifted out of poverty” expressed Alh. Magaji. With this loan, Alh. Magaji is well on his way to achieving this dream.

loans.use: to access high-quality inputs such as fertilizer and seed in order to double income and yield.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchases more drugs for his pharmacy.

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en:
Gideon, 23, is a very passionate dairy farmer, based in Litein, Kenya. He is committed to his newly-wedded wife, with whom they have been blessed with a baby boy. 

Like most smallholder rural farmers in Kenya, Gideon is a mixed farmer. From the age of 15, he has been selling his produce, which includes milk, tea, and other crops at the local market. Gideon is also engaged in other side businesses. When asked, he stated that he enjoys dairy farming. However, he admitted to having challenges managing his tea crops in their initial stages. 

Gideon is seeking a loan to purchase a dairy cow. The cow he is looking for is the high quality type that goes for KES 65,000. This type of cow produces 15 to 20 liters of milk daily. This is quite superior to common local breeds that produce three to five liters a day. 

Your loan will help Gideon make enough money from the additional cow to enable him to pay for his new family’s upkeep expenses. He stated that the loan will benefit his family by providing him with the ability to meet his family’s basic needs.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Santos Obdulio

texts.es: Santos, tiene 41 años de edad, es soltero, tiene un hijo y reside en el municipio de Nueva Frontera, Santa Bárbara.
